Participants.evidence: patients who underwent open surgery for gynecologic malignancies using ERAS protocols from March 2016 to December 2018

Intervention.evidence: Participants were divided into two cohorts based on the presence or absence of postoperative AKI within 30 days.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the development of long-term chronic kidney disease (CKD) and cardiac conditions postoperatively among patients who did and did not develop acute kidney injury (AKI) after open ERAS surgery for gynecologic malignancy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the 36-month cumulative incidence of CKD.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Over a median follow-up of 19.4 months, patients with AKI were twice as likely to develop CKD (p<0.001).

Result_Outcome.evidence: On univariate analysis, AKI was associated with CKD (HR=2.17, 95% CI 1.22–3.84)

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
